Your mental health seems stable! Keep up the good work! Maintain a balanced routine, enjoy what you do, and rest well. Stay joyful and healthy!

At this stage, it’s important to monitor your mental well-being. Consider taking short breaks, engaging in light physical activities, and maintaining a healthy sleep routine. If symptoms persist, consulting a mental health professional could help.

Your mental health may benefit from reducing your workload and taking regular breaks. Establish a consistent sleep schedule and focus on stress-reducing activities. Don’t hesitate to consult a mental health professional for personalized guidance.

It’s crucial to address your well-being by balancing rest, relaxation, and work. Light physical activities, such as walking or stretching, can help ease anxiety. Please consult a mental health professional as soon as possible to get support and create a tailored plan for recovery.

If you\'re feeling overwhelmed or unable to manage daily activities, seeking immediate assistance from a mental health professional is essential. They can offer the necessary support and help you navigate this challenging time. Take a break from any stressful commitments and prioritize your health above all.
Input should be 1 hour to 12 hours
World Mental Health Day falls on October 10
Our best mental health tips - backed by research,

Protecting our mental health is easier than you might think. We can all do it every day, and with simple activities that help us feel good, we’re better able to cope with life. Each of our tips has been created to help us look after our mental health. Importantly, each one is backed up by evidence from research, including the Mental Health Foundation’s ground-breaking study.

1. Get closer to nature: We all live with worries and fears, uncertainties, losses that leave us sad and pressures that make us feel stressed. Nature can have a really calming effect on us.

2. Get more from your sleep: Anyone who has struggled with sleep will know what a difference it makes to our bodies, minds and ability to cope with life.

3. Keep moving: Our bodies and minds are connected, so looking after ourselves physically also helps us prevent problems with our mental health (it works the other way around, too).

4. Eat healthy food: Food and drink affect our bodies, brains and mood – for good or bad.

5. Be kind and help create a better world: If you have ever felt lonely, you will know how much it helps to have even a small connection with someone else.

6. Be curious and open-minded to new experiences: We can all get stuck in familiar ways, like how we spend our time and what we think about ourselves and the world.

7. Plan things to look forward to: Life throws all sorts at us, and during hard times, we may feel hopeless and not have the energy to plan for the future.

8. Learn to understand and manage your feelings: Feeling very upset can interfere with our lives, making it hard to think clearly or work, relax, study, sleep or deal with other people.

9. Talk to someone you trust for support: Many of us have learned to bottle things up inside us and try to ignore painful feelings. It can take a lot of courage to tell someone else how we’re feeling or what we’re finding hard, especially if we don’t usually do that kind of thing.

10. Be aware of using drugs and/or alcohol to cope with difficult feelings: Many of us sometimes use drugs to block out “difficult” feelings such as sadness, fear or shame.

This year, World Mental Health Day falls on October 10. The importance of mental health has become a concern and priority for everyone.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), nearly one in seven adolescents aged 10 to 19 lives with some form of mental health condition.

The History of World Mental Health Day

As reported by National Today, World Mental Health Day was initiated by the WFMH in 1992, led by then Deputy Secretary-General Richard Hunter. Its purpose was to educate the public about mental health overall. The celebration featured a worldwide television broadcast conveying messages to the public about mental health.

The theme of the first World Mental Health Day in 1994 was "Improving the Quality of Mental Health Services Throughout the World."

From 1995 onward, the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) expanded World Mental Health Day campaigns to Spain, France, Russia, Hindi, Japan, China, and Arabic-speaking countries. Since 2013, WHO has organized a global campaign for World Mental Health Day every year. At the United Nations (UN), events and activities are held annually during October to promote the importance of mental health.

Reference:
https://www.kompas.tv/article/336489/10-oktober-hari-kesehatan-mental-dunia-2022-waspada-tingkat-bunuh-diri-remaja

Mental disorders are clinically significant disturbances in cognition, emotion, or behavior, often causing distress or impairing daily functioning.
They include conditions like anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, PTSD, schizophrenia, eating disorders, and neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., ADHD, autism).
In 2019, 1 in 8 people globally (970 million) lived with a mental disorder, with anxiety and depressive disorders being the most prevalent.
The COVID-19 pandemic caused a sharp increase in these conditions.

Key Disorders:
1. Anxiety Disorders (301 million in 2019): Excessive fear or worry, often treated with therapy and medication.
2. Depression (280 million): Persistent sadness, low energy, and suicide risk; therapy and medication are effective.
3. Bipolar Disorder (40 million): Alternates between depressive and manic episodes; treated with psychoeducation and medication.
4. PTSD: Triggered by trauma, marked by flashbacks and avoidance; therapy is effective.
5. Schizophrenia (24 million): Involves delusions, hallucinations, and cognitive impairment; treated with medication and rehabilitation.
6. Eating Disorders (14 million): Includes anorexia and bulimia, associated with severe health risks; therapy is key.
7. Disruptive Behavior Disorders (40 million): Persistent defiance or rule violations, treated with cognitive training.
8. Neurodevelopmental Disorders: ADHD, autism, and intellectual disabilities; managed with behavioral interventions and therapy.

Challenges and Risks:
Mental disorders are exacerbated by factors like poverty, violence, and inequality.
Health systems remain under-resourced, with many lacking access to effective care.
Stigma and discrimination further hinder recovery.

WHO Response:
The WHO’s Mental Health Action Plan (2013–2030) aims to:
1. Strengthen governance and leadership for mental health.
2. Provide community-based, integrated care.
3. Promote prevention and mental health strategies.
4. Enhance research and information systems.

The WHO’s mhGAP program expands services in low-resource settings, offering tools and training for managing mental disorders effectively.

Mental.ly is a leading mental health application designed to provide comprehensive support and resources for individuals facing mental health challenges. With an easy-to-use interface and advanced features, Mental.ly aims to revolutionize the way people manage and improve their mental well-being.
